dublin_core.dcvalue: brown, d. & Jordan, M. E. (2018). Influence of Perceptions of Past Collaborative Experiences on Quality of Pre-service Collaboration and Outcomes. In Kay, J. and Luckin, R. (Eds.) Rethinking Learning in the Digital Age: Making the Learning Sciences Count, 13th International Conference of the Learning Sciences (ICLS) 2018, Volume 3. London, UK: International Society of the Learning Sciences.

Abstract: This qualitative interpretive study used content and discourse analysis to examine pre-service teachers’ perceptions of past collaborative efforts, and how those perceptions influenced their collaboration in four-member groups during design and delivery of a collaborative instructional project. Participants (N=24) were in their first semester of under-graduate teacher preparation. Qualitative data from written-reflections, semi-structured interviews and recorded audio-video observations were collected and compared to an ordinal ranking of groups’ collaborative instruction. Content analysis indicated pre-service perceptions of past collaborative experiences could be characterized as either a flexible orientation toward collaboration or an inflexible orientation toward collaboration. Discourse analysis indicated that pre-service perceptions of past collaborative experiences impacted students’ current collaborative efforts and outcomes. Students with a flexible orientation collaborated with higher quality interactions than students with an inflexible orientation. In turn, groups with members having a flexible orientation created and delivered higher quality collaborative instruction than groups with only members having an inflexible orientation.
